data.text:
I've been doing a lot of reading - links to just a few

analogRead() - Arduino Reference

analogReference() - Arduino Reference

About the AREF pin – Arduino Help Center

Can I use a 3.3 V rated sensor with a 5 V operating board? – Arduino Help Center

But I still don't have a 100% clear answer so to the forum I go...

I am using a MKR WiFi 1010 with a MKR GPS shield, MKR ENV shield and a couple of analog sensors on it;

A K30 CO2 sensor , with output 0-4 V representing 0-2000 ppm, but because the MKR can only accept up to a 3.3 V signal I used a voltage divider of 4.7k and 1k to knock output max down from 4 to 3.29V.

And an analog Anemometer which has an output 0.4-2 V, representing 0-32.4 m/s.

In the sketch I am converting the analog signal from the anemometer to windspeed using a mapfloat function. And the analog signal from the K30 is just being converted to a raw voltage. This is because I am doing an external calibration on the sensor , from which I can find a linear equation which converts the analog voltage to a CO2 concentration.

My question is: Can I use the MKR's default of 3.3V as the reference voltage for converting the signal from both sensors. This is higher than the span of the anemometer's signal, but from what I could tell this may just affect the resolution (though in what manner I do not know)? Do I use one of the lower internal built in references and add more resistance to the K30? Is there a logical way to determine which sensor should I cater to (aside from which is more important for my application) ?

Thanks!
